item.title: Tariffs are taxes and they were used to finance the federal government until the 1913 income tax. A top economist breaks it down
item.description: The last major U.S. tariff law was the Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act of 1930, which established an average tariff rate of 20% on all imports by 1933.

item.title: Sheryl Sandberg breaks down why it’s a troubling time for women in the workplace right now
item.description: Hundreds of thousands of working women left the U.S. workforce this year, while issues of gender stereotyping, workplace harassment, and lackluster ca...

item.title: Leading the agentic enterprise: What the next wave of AI demands from CEOs
item.description: With agentic AI on board, companies must rethink their very makeup: how work is designed, how decisions are made, and how value is created.

item.title: Asia will get steady growth next year, defying global headwinds, says Mastercard’s chief APAC economist
item.description: Asia is contributing more to global growth than the Americas or Europe, says Mastercard's David Mann.

item.title: Honest Company CEO Carla Vernón on being mentored by Walmart’s Doug McMillon
item.description: Also: All the news and watercooler chat from Fortune.
